pros: The work I do feels legitimately meaningful. The biggest benefit to a job in a hospital is that you never feel like your job is pointless. It makes it easy to get up in the morning, do the work to the best of your ability, and go home feeling satisfied.
cons: Besides the cons that come with any healthcare job (mostly much higher stress,) the biggest problem here is the management. They appear receptive at first glance but ultimately provide nothing at all and will outright ignore what you tell them. Training quality was horrendous and nearly drove me to quit the job. Department is constantly understaffed, but management is obsessed with keeping it this way (there's 3 roles during the day that are never filled, and we're on call because they aren't willing to fill late-night positions to have more staff than needed.) I find it hard to believe the company can't afford to staff just 5 or 6 more people so we can have all roles filled and not require on-call. Supposedly we're almost fully staffed though. Again, all of these are management problems.

review_title: Great place to work without a degree- unlimited opportunity.
job_title: Central Supply Technician in Rio Rancho, NM
pros:
Presbyterian is a huge organization that needs every skill set there is. So everyone's experience will be different. But it's a great place for people without degrees to work because there is pretty much unlimited opportunity for advancement if you do good and play your cards right. You don't need a degree to advance high with pres and make a good living. There were lots of managers who got the position the old fashioned way. By just working hard and proving themselves.

My skill set is in logistics... I started as a central supply tech at Rust making $16.50 an hour. After three years and two promotions I'm sitting at $20 an hour. There is so much room to grow if you apply yourself and don't start drama.

A lot of what you experience comes down to the kind of management you have. When I first started I had a terrible and abusive supervisor who bullied, talked down to and berated the staff. But the staff went to HR and HR got rid of that supervisor very quickly after an investigation. They take that stuff seriously... Which is wonderful. The new supervisor that was transferred in was a great guy who didn't hold the staff back and encouraged growth.

The culture at Presbyterian is refreshing. HR is scary effective at rooting out abusive or bad managers which makes it an ideal place to work for those looking to start a career. They genuinely seem to care about the staff and they give regular raises... They will even give all staff things like $2000 bonuses and an extra 40 hours of PTO out of the blue. Presbyterian wants to be competitive... And they are not afraid to spend money to be that way.

Work/life balance is great in every area I've worked in. There would sometimes be pressure to do OT but it was never forced on you. The supervisor I had understood and accommodated the needs of staff with family. I don't think I've ever had a day off denied while at Presbyterian. But I know it's different for clinical staff from what I've heard.

As for pay... It's fair and genuinely competitive for support staff from what I've seen. One thing to keep in mind is that pay is exclusively based on experience listed on your resume. So make sure it's all listed. I use two resumes at Presbyterian. One of them is short and pretty to get the attention of hiring managers. The other is less pretty but has every bit of experience I have itemized so HR will give me the pay I deserve. I recommend you do the same.

Overall I'm happy at Presbyterian. I'm treated with respect, the work is rewarding, I'm compensated fairly and I feel like I'm in control of my career with very few barriers to achieving my goals.

I spent 10 years working a dead end logistics job with little room for advancement. And it feels like I wasted a decade of my life there. I don't feel that way about Presbyterian. My only regret is that I didn't join earlier.
cons: It's not all good... But you are generally able to effect change to fix the things that aren't good if you keep a level head and act in good faith. Just remember that pay is almost exclusively based on the experience listed on your resume. So get that resume right.

review_title: AAS does not care about patients or employees
pros: Pay, experience, education, and the field team are the only redeeming factors working in favor of albuquerque ambulance
cons:
Chief Kasper, and the Command Suite by extension, does not care about his employees and has made it abundantly clear to all of the field staff that the present politic between AAS and it's parent company Presbyterian Healthcare Services is more important. 

The overall image of AAS, especially in the eyes of PHS, is more important than giving equal respect to its "boots on ground" employees. He has created a toxic work environment that violates the base trust required for EMTs to work in the highly volatile and fluid field that we are otherwise accustomed to. He deals harshly with criticism, even among command staff, and then flaunts that there is very little outspoken criticism as if that were a mark of success rather than one of silent fear. There is a reason why the turnover rate is so high and they promote people with less than a year of experience to the rank of CPT; it is because AAS does not support its people despite giving the outward appearance of doing so through the bare minimum of actions. 

People here who have worked longer than 3-4 years will describe being stuck here and the near universal climate is that everyone is here to get their "high volume experience" and jump ship to other ambulance companies, flight, or fire; that is if they haven't been totally burned out on EMS as a whole and leave the career field completely (which happens often as well).

review_title: A non-state entity with a state employee mentality-Health Plan
pros: Large company with many opportunities, if you are lucky enough to have a manager who cares. Otherwise, consider your prospects for advancement limited at best, sabotaged at worst.
cons: This company is in dire need of new blood. While many people have been with the company for many years, the experience you learn if you are new is great. However most are no longer effective and are "married" to the status quo. Don't even think about wanting to improve things. If the wrong manager catches wind of it, your life will be made miserable until you leave or they fire you. This company is about 10 years behind other insurance companies in terms of technology, client/customer/broker engagement and information tracking. There are no reporting mechanisms on the health plan side to really determine what works, what doesn't, where to really place sales strategy or the like. It really is just a shot in the dark or what underwriting may come up with statistically. There are so many manual processes that it is no wonder administration costs are so expensive.

pros: The technology available helps make the RN job role more streamlined.

pros: The vast majority of the people are great - caring and focused on the mission of taking care of the patient. As the largest non-government employer in the state, there are plenty of opportunities to find meaningful work within the organization.
cons: Decisions are made by committees, but the ones on the committees are not necessarily the ones who will be impacted by the decisions. This makes decisions take longer than needed, and regularly catches people off-guard when decisions that impact them are implements without warning. Also, a large portion of the employees have been there for extended period of time, and over time accumulate power (indirect or otherwise) over information or processes, and make it harder to make improvements, or causes a huge amount of stress when they leave and people start finding out what they were handling unofficially.

job_title: Systems Analyst III in Albuquerque, NM
pros: Aside from management the employees are nice and very friendly. I made a lot of friends there, some that I still keep in contact with today.
cons: They find the least qualified person and promote them to leadership (Directors, managers, CIO etc.) . They get huge bonuses (30K or more) every year on top of their $100.00+ hourly salary all while telling employees they can't afford a raise or all they can afford is a 2% raise for your department. Of course they get a raise every year. One of the directors was bragging about going from $65.00 an hour to $82.00 now. Employees also get no bonus, unless you count a 10 dollar gift card to Smiths every Christmas. Your job will constantly be threatened by outsourcing to save the company money. In the last 3 years I had to reapply for my job 4 times and had a change of title 3 times. A current employee recently told me they finally did make good on the outsourcing, which should be complete by October 2012. That should allow for a bigger bonus for all the leadership that had a hand in it.This wouldn't be so bad if Presbyterian wasn't a Non profit organization, that is supposed to be there to help the community. Now you know why your hospital bills are so expensive. The money to pay the hundreds of leadership has to come from somewhere, and the saddest part is it comes from the sick people of New Mexico.

pros:

Scheduling of patients does not support continuity of care leading to poorer patient outcomes.

Continual roll out of new HR driven initiatives which are ostensibly designed to improve patient care. The actual focus is way off target, and they just end up with loads of acronyms that don't improve anything, just waste clinicians' time and the company's money. Meetings to reenforce these initiatives gives you the feeling of being in a cult. 

Pay is mid range to low for this market.

Innovation is not supported by the glacial pace of change in such an enormous bureaucracy. 

Technology is not reliable and often increases work load.

review_title: Great Company, but very hard to get employed
job_title: Patient Access Advocate I in Albuquerque, NM
pros:
Benefits- 401k, PTO starts on your first day, competitive health insurance starts on your first day, paid training
Their story from where they started which spills into their values is beautiful! I lived by the CARES values.
cons: During my training on EPIC software, I was required after 2 weeks to pass a "Skills Check" test with an 85% or higher. If you did not pass, you were terminated. The test itself was on every department that has registration (ER, L&D, Front Desk, GI Surgery,etc) even if it wasn't your department you were hired for. I felt like that's a lot of unnecessary pressure for an entry level job that barely pays over the minimum wage.  After termination, even if you were "an eligble rehire" leaving on good terms, through HR you were still deemed "ineligible" and couldn't apply for 2 years. I had to fight tooth and nail on the wrongful terminology to get back into the company.

review_title: Best place to work in New Mexico.
pros: For New Mexico employers it doesn't get any better than this. Great leadership team that will continue to help Presbyterian make the right decisions to navigate through the current healthcare industry transformation.  Best job mission with great employees who care. Salary and benefits are among the best in New Mexico. They promote living a healthy lifestyle including gym membership as part of the benefits.
cons:
The annual rhythm (strategic planning and budgeting) needs some realignment so planning activities are placed appropriately relative to annual operating budget planning. The speed of change in the Health plan is also a key driver for realignment.
Years of business growth without an appropriate level of staff growth has created a severe work/life balance issue, especially within IT. Long time employees have lost the work ethic and often not held accountable.

job_title: Emergency Department RN in Rio Rancho, NM
pros: My department management team is amazing! They fight tooth and nail for our department and our team. They legitimately care about us and make the most out of every opportunity for improvement they are allowed to pursue. Our department is very supportive of each other and, with very few exceptions, our providers are a dream to work with. I have gained alot of knowledge, experience, and industry connections in my time here. Great place to learn and grow.
cons: There has been a culture shift over the past few years that our ED management team has shielded us from really well, but COVID-19 just magnified the brewing dysfunction. I think this is true about alot of the medical field in these trying times, but I believed this company was different. I had faith that they would walk their talk in good times and bad times. They didn't. Not worse than others in the area, just not better in terms of putting patients before profits. Also, as a company, they struggle to think outside the box when needed, act proactively to known challenges, and make use of available resources.

review_title: Management needs its own RX written
pros: Worked with some good people and I liked the short commute.   Don't have anymore positive comments even though this site insists you write minimum 20 words.
cons:
How can management not know females are harassed?   Male employee's always finding an excuse to "hug" a female coworker.   Several males openly discussing that they "would like to tap that" referring to a female nurse.  Tracking and watching the nurse on a security screen.   

Christmas 2016 our Christmas party was held in the cafeteria.  We were told no alcohol because it was inside the hospital.  What management did not tell employees is that Pres events on hospital premises for physicians often involve alcohol.  Double standards.  

Why is housekeeping allowed to get away with "we are too busy" to respond to clean ups or remove trash?   

Why does it take HR so long to fill slots- hospital ends up paying premium for agency staffing and we were left short handed.

pros:
-Work from home (some positions)
-Relative flexibility in scheduling the work you need to do
-Management is very, very close to all their employees which is not something you will see anywhere else. They will take time to talk to you and are very approachable. It's a very comfortable atmosphere
-Very accommodating with travel - they pay for hotels, rental cars (including upgrades to four wheel drive vehicles in winter/bad weather), amazing per diem rates, 54.5 cents/mile reimbursement when using own vehicle which adds up fast for telecommute workers
cons:
-Sometimes receive direction from several managers other than your own whom you may not even know. Sometimes you will receive conflicting direction which can be frustrating to sort out
-Benefits are pretty bad considering it's a medical insurance company. You pay for all your medical bills until you hit the deductible which under my plan is $7k. Then they will start to kick in 80%. That plan for a family is around $130/pay period. You can get better coverage but you will pay a lot more

At PHP it is not as much about what you know, your education, knowledge and experience, it is more about who you know. It is hard to get a job here if you do not have an inside person that you are close too. Than if you do get a job here without knowing anyone the team is rude and gang up on you, treats you horribly, leaves you out of things, and makes you feel like an outsider. 
There is no real chance for advancement if you do not know anyone. That means you have to be someone's neighbor, best friend, neighbor, or family member, otherwise you will not have the opportunity to advance. 
Also, the raises are a joke, they are non-existent and they beat around the bush about not giving a raise. Even with nothing but high scores on you annual review there is not a lot of opportunity given or raises for that matter. 
They were having financial issues before being sued and now they are being sued by the Attorney General. They claim that this is all just not true. But the Attorney General is not going to put his reputation on the line just to go after an insurance company that is innocent. Also, if you are being sued for not paying what you should, where is all the money going? Why the financial issues? This is not the first time Presbyterian has decided not to give raises, yet raise the amount of all of our benefits. 
That is another thing, they tell LPN's get your RN, Associate, now they are telling both LPN's and RN-Associates to get there BSN in order to advance and be a manager. To get a BSN costs anywhere from $20,000 to $50,000 and you are not giving raises. So now employees are supposed to go into even more debt to advance, only to not receive a raise. 
That brings me to another aspect, why is it so hard to talk to a Human Resources Representative? They have HR locked up like Fort Knox and if you try to go speak to someone from HR then you get  advised to call AskHR so you call and the person answering doesn't know what to do, so they transfer you to someone else to leave a voicemail, only that HR person does not call you back. Crazy.
Benefits: I came to this organization for benefits and the cost to me keeps going up. When I first got Presbyterian Insurance they had no PCP's to see. It is hard to get seen, even at their UC which will tell you they are at capacity, even if you are really sick or bleeding. So then you ask for a list of covered providers and they do not have one. I have Presbyterian insurance and I do not even go see Presbyterian Providers because every time I tried to get into a Presbyterian provider it was a hassle.
